author: developeruche
content:
The benchmark report is ready;

https://hackmd.io/nz8dncoPRY6btL_uOQmWpQ#Total-Round-Trip-Time

Raw log: https://github.com/developeruche/witness-bench/blob/main/RAW_REPORT.md

Report shows latency improvement whe `debug_executionWitness` is paired with `engine_newPayload`

author: taulepton_
content: <@944007601400741989> can you inform us of what transport mechanism you used here? Was this http? Can you evaluate performance with ipc?

author: taulepton_
content: Great work by the way

author: developeruche
content: Yeah‚Ä¶ http

author: developeruche
content: Sure, I can evaluate over IPC

author: taulepton_
content: Awesome, thanks!

author: taulepton_
content: My takeaway is that the transport and serialization overhead is huge for large witnesses. I think we want to bypass transport entirely. I think we will need to have both the prover and the node on the same server. Using either a fast ssd drive or ram (memfd) to pass the witness from the node to the prover. cc: <@774033563732541451> <@466102668138512394> <@427491045308235776>

author: jsign
content: I think makes sense. We can use files at the "software layer" (i.e. CL), and leave to the node operator to optimize further using memfd if everything runs in the same machine (which prob is a good idea in general).

author: jsign
content: Thanks for you analysis! Did you have the chance to experiment with doing some ssz serialization to experiment how to see how changes a bit the JSON-overhead?

author: kevaundray
content:
> I think we will need to have both the prover and the node on the same server.
This would be non-ideal I think because then the prover would have a stateful component. Perhaps this is where we eventually land at though after more investigation. 

For further investigation, I think it may make sense to play around with different serializations/compression formats. 

Another route is pricing out these worse case witnesses (by having the witness size be a requirement instead of a byproduct) and or not fully committing until we verify what it looks like with binary trees

author: kevaundray
content:
What does the /Overhead part mean in "Transport / Overhead" ?

If possible would be great if you had more detail on whats happening here üôè  (just trying to figure out exactly what and why its so high)

author: developeruche
content:
<@774033563732541451> I haven't tested SSZ yet since I was sticking to the current Engine API JSON-RPC specs, but you're right sending 500MB of hex-encoded bytes is definitely a worst-case scenario for transport ovrhead.

Could explain more on what you mean me here? with what I have in my head, it would entail changing the transport layer data format of the node to SSZ which is quite a heavy lift for a PoC üôÇ

author: jsign
content:
Ah, I was thinking on maybe some potential benefit of a currently proposed EIP to use SSZ at the EL. 
I was thinking more like just compraing raw JSON vs SSZ serialization maybe isolated -- not sure it is worth redoing the whole engineAPI to use SSZ for this since hta sounds quite a lot of work.

author: developeruche
content: got you! this would be really nice IMO, it cuts down data size by 50%

author: jsign
content:
> Another route is pricing out these worse case witnesses (by having the witness size be a requirement instead of a byproduct) and or not fully committing until we verify what it looks like with binary trees
Yeah, actually 500MiB will be small compared with upcoming gas limit increases. ha
These worst cases should become better with BT due to bytecode chunking -- this will be a must to solve the killers coming from the bytecode attacks that generate those cases, so makes senes to maybe not overfit trying to deal with those

author: jsign
content: Some extra thoguhts about the: "files API interface". Might be good to see what some CL-core-devs think about this.. feels like a new "interface type" that is quite weirdish compared with what exist today in their impls?

author: jsign
content: Sophisticated builders prob will build their own pipeline ofc

author: developeruche
taulepton_
content:
> This would be non-ideal I think because then the prover would have a stateful component. Perhaps this is where we eventually land at though after more investigation. 

Could you elaborate on this a little more, please? I don't follow

author: taulepton_
content:
> Some extra thoguhts about the: "files API interface". Might be good to see what some CL-core-devs think about this.. feels like a new "interface type" that is quite weirdish compared with what exist today in their impls? 

<@774033563732541451>  Does the CL layer have to be involved here? The expectation would be that the prover has access to the witnesses required to execute the block / new payload request that the CL requests via the api.

author: kevaundray
content: Currently we can send a prover the initial witness + program to prove, so they don't hold any state and are not aware of "Ethereum state" essentially

author: taulepton_
content: Yep that makes sense but it looked like transport was a pretty considerable overhead from the benchmarks.

author: taulepton_
content: I 'd like to see if ipc improves things

author: kevaundray
content: Ah okay I see -- might be good to know exactly what is taking up the majority of the time

author: taulepton_
content: http is likely a significant overhead

author: taulepton_
content: ipc will improve it somewhat

author: taulepton_
content: serialization format reduces data size

author: kevaundray
content: I also wonder how compressible it is on average

author: taulepton_
content: good point, regarding compression.

author: taulepton_
content: <@944007601400741989> was this benchmark performed on localhost?

author: taulepton_
content: i.e. both services on the same machine?

author: kevaundray
content:
This would make sense -- it would be good to get the exact measurements so I can extrapolate to what it means in terms of isolated components (haven't checked out the code, so I may just be being overly cautious)

For example, for the JSON part, I'm extrapolating that these benchmarks are saying that it takes 2 seconds to json serialize a 500MB payload

author: taulepton_
content: yep that was my interpretation and then 4.6 seconds to transfer over the wire

author: taulepton_
content: but 4.6 seconds seems very high for 500mb of data

author: taulepton_
content: I wonder if JSON serialisation is bloating the size

author: developeruche
content: yeah... local host, same machine

author: taulepton_
content: <@944007601400741989> would you be able to report on the size of the json serialized witness please?

author: developeruche
content: you mean the size of the witness data before it was serialize to json?

author: taulepton_
content: before and after

author: kevaundray
content: Yeah exactly, I wonder how much data is being transferred here and the transfer rate

author: taulepton_
content: I assumed the size you have in the report is before seriliaztion?

author: developeruche
content: This size is after JSON serialization

author: developeruche
content: I didn't add this to the log report, but for all the cases it was approx 50% less the JSON serialized output

author: taulepton_
content: wow yeah thats pretty bad

author: taulepton_
content: super useful that we have these statistics early so we can design to optimise this

author: taulepton_
content: <@944007601400741989> I would propose you add a note about the json serialisation size bloat, I think thats a pretty important point

author: kevaundray
content: Github seems to still be down üôÅ <@944007601400741989> could you put the repo and branch in the hackmd?

author: developeruche
developeruche
content: sure!

author: kevaundray
content: If the size is halved, then does it mean that 250MB is taking ~4 seconds to transfer over the wire on localhost?

author: taulepton_
content: I think if it doubles the size of the data for the encoding format, then it's inefficient. Why do you think its reasonable?

author: taulepton_
content: I suspect that transport overhead is also capturing json deserialization?

author: taulepton_
content: json deserialization is also pretty annoying becuase you have to wait for the full data to arrive until you can start to deserialize

author: taulepton_
content: `witnessBytes = &wb` is this just rlp encoded bytes?

author: developeruche
content: I think it is still 500mb data size, since the 250mb would be serialized before transit, though, I was exepcting a faster speed even with 500mb data size

author: taulepton_
content: bytes are inefficient with json becuase its encoded to a hex string, essentially doubling the size (2 nibble chars per byte). which is consistent with what you reported.

author: developeruche
content: Yeah, that makes alot of sense thinking on this

author: jsign
content: If the way that the witness is provided is via engine_{get|new}Payload, doesn't this mean that the CL should transfer the witness to the prover (e.g. zkboost)? This is why I was assuming this "file API" involved CL.

author: developeruche
content: yeah

author: taulepton_
content: Could you elaborate on what you mean by "file API" here? I was thinking the prover should be expected to fetch a witness from a co-located  witness database or file.

author: jsign
content: What I mean is that if the prover (e.g. zkboost) will read from a co-located database/file/folder, then the entity creating that database-entry/file/folder is the CL, no?

author: taulepton_
content: I guess it depends how we architect things

author: taulepton_
content: So the CL should invoke new_payload on the engineAPI. Then call request_proofs on the prover, and the prover should fetch the witness from the witness database.

author: taulepton_
content: Are you proposing that the CL should provide a reference to the file for the prover to fetch from?

author: jsign
content: If the prover relies in some co-located file/database/etc, then from my perspective the CL is doing the write to that place. Thus this is some new responsibility of the CL, compared to only have as a communication layer the current RPCs.

author: jsign
content: If not, who is saving that witness into the database/file/etc?

author: taulepton_
content: The idea would be the EL

author: taulepton_
content: I.e. a reth exex

author: jsign
content:
Shouldn't this be a standarized feature in all ELs? Feels to me if this is critical to have good enough performance, we need to add it as a full feature in ELs.
(My point is that if this is done by CL or ELs -- feels like a new kind of feature in them to get some feedback from those core devs)

author: taulepton_
content: Right got you

author: taulepton_
content: yes agreed

author: taulepton_
content: By the way we have implemented a witness indexer using reth exex that uses postcard to serialize and persist in reth db. I will try and complete testing this week and share with you guys.

author: jsign
content: Also, if this is done by ELs instead of CLs, sounds like in that case we wouldn't go the engine_{get|new}Payload route providing the witness, no?

author: taulepton_
content: Yes agreed

author: taulepton_
content: I think it would be a really nice interface to use engine_* methods but this overhead is prohibitive imo

author: taulepton_
content: I suppose we can explore binary encoding + compression to see if we can make it viable.

author: kevaundray
content: <@944007601400741989> could you also try with ethrex? They added in some optimzations recently related to the execution witness like: https://github.com/lambdaclass/ethrex/pull/6058
